author.name: by Michelle Patten, Paul Riddle, Pavan Tauh and Ben Wise

items.title: General Findings:
items.summary: Overall, we have found that disease spread faster than Europeans could travel. Just from their landing, Native Americans caught diseases and spread them to other tribes and cities. Due to this rapid spread, Europeans viewed the Native American populations as sicker and thinner than normal.
items.content_html:
Overall, we have found that disease spread faster than Europeans could travel. Just from their landing, Native Americans caught diseases and spread them to other tribes and cities. Due to this rapid spread, Europeans viewed the Native American populations as sicker and thinner than normal. 

To address our original question, disease spread organically far more than by European force. Smallpox blankets and other forms of biological warfare may have hurt small groups of Natives during battle, but many Native Americans caught diseases before seeing a European.

author.name: by Michelle Patten, Paul Riddle, Pavan Tauh and Ben Wise

items.content_html:
Pavan Tauh is a sophomore at UT Dallas studying Biology. He is proficient in website design and research gathering. He became involved in this project from interest in researching factors that lead to the disease spreading through the Native American population so quickly.  Outside of class, Pavan is an avid photographer who enjoys hiking through nature, going to the beach, and cruising on his skateboard.  

Contact Information: pkt180000@utdallas.edu

author.name: by Michelle Patten, Paul Riddle, Pavan Tauh and Ben Wise

items.title: Syphilis
items.summary: Researchers debate the origin of syphilis, and usually agree with one of two theories. The first states that syphilis existed in Europe before Columbus returned, and that it was misdiagnosed as other diseases. The other theory states that it came from the Americas and spread…
items.content_html:
Researchers debate the origin of syphilis, and usually agree with one of two theories. The first states that syphilis existed in Europe before Columbus returned, and that it was misdiagnosed as other diseases. The other theory states that it came from the Americas and spread along Europe only after Columbus returned. 

From our data, the shape of a spread appears for syphilis reportings in Europe and Asia. This support the idea that European explorers brought the disease back with them, while before syphilis existed only in the New World.

author.name: by Michelle Patten, Paul Riddle, Pavan Tauh and Ben Wise

items.title: Method
items.summary: To begin our project, we accumulated data from online scholarly articles and books from our library. We searched for maps, movements of diseases and facts of disease spread. We also emailed tribal leaders for any information and guidance they could provide. Next, we compiled these…
items.content_html:
To begin our project, we accumulated data from online scholarly articles and books from our library. We searched for maps, movements of diseases and facts of disease spread. We also emailed tribal leaders for any information and guidance they could provide.

Next, we compiled these datapoints into an Excel sheet and added metadata to help with the graphing process. We noted the date, location, disease, source, and any related information that could either explain or be explained from this event.

At the same time, we built a website first through WordPress, but eventually we changed it to GitHub, using Publii to design it. We looked to other map projects such as Photogrammar and al Turraya to learn what features were possible in Leaflet (our mapping tool), and which ones we wanted to add to our own map.

As we gained new insights, we wrote them down into a PowerPoint and document. We presented what knowledge we gained to our peers. With their help, we created a document with feedback and ways for us to improve and clarify our project.

The map came next, with us adding datapoints to create a basic map in leaflet.

Finally, we compiled our information online. 

These tools were chosen to help us create our project in an efficient and accurate way. Microsoft Word and Google Docs were used to write, with Word being superior offline and Docs being superior for collaboration. Google Sheets allowed each of us to add datapoints gathered to a common place. These datapoints allowed us to build the map in Leaflet, which we chose for its features (gathered in other DH projects) and compatibility. Github and Publii were chosen to build and host the website. A peer recommended these programs to us, and we enjoyed using them.

author.name: by Michelle Patten, Paul Riddle, Pavan Tauh and Ben Wise

items.title: Map
items.summary: While our map is currently under contruction, presented above is a snapshot with our datapoints for Syphilis plotted in grey. As we progress we hope to add different map overlays and connect the points of common diseases to create a visual web.

items.title: Paul Riddle
items.summary: Paul Riddle is a junior undergraduate National Merit Scholar studying molecular biology at the University of Texas at Dallas. He aspires to research diseases’ methods of attack in order to develop novel treatment and is planning on obtaining a doctoral degree in this field before…
items.content_html: Paul Riddle is a junior undergraduate National Merit Scholar studying molecular biology at the University of Texas at Dallas. He aspires to research diseases’ methods of attack in order to develop novel treatment and is planning on obtaining a doctoral degree in this field before moving into a career of disease research. His hobbies include hiking when home in Seattle, reading science fiction and fantasy epics, and working in Dr. Dennis Miller’s molecular biology laboratory at UTD. He hopes New World Epidemiology’s look into the diseases that devastated Native Americans brings new understanding of pathogens’ extraordinary effect on human history, as well as our responsibility to manage this threat moving forward.

Aside from research, she spends most of her time climbing or writing for the university's opinion magazine.

author.name: by Michelle Patten, Paul Riddle, Pavan Tauh and Ben Wise

items.title: Introduction
items.summary: While colonizing the Americas, European explorers purposefully spread diseases completely foreign to the land’s natives. The Native Americans had no time to build immune defenses to these often deliberately galvanized pathogens and thus suffered heavily. We, the authors, set out to see if the spread…
items.content_html:
While colonizing the Americas, European explorers purposefully spread diseases completely foreign to the land’s natives. The Native Americans had no time to build immune defenses to these often deliberately galvanized pathogens and thus suffered heavily.

 We, the authors, set out to see if the spread of disease was caused more by European colonists or by regular disease spread. 

    1. Info on Columbian Exchange
    2. Historiography
